citations.narrative:
The transporter has not maintained records for the dogs that they have transported within the past year. Failure to
maintain the required recordkeeping information for the required amount of time can inhibit accurate identification and
tracking of animals. The facility must make, keep, and maintain all records or forms required by this subpart for a period of
1 year after an animal is delivered, euthanized, or disposed of and for any period in excess of one year as necessary to
comply with any applicable Federal, State, or local law. To be corrected by 7/20/2025.

The transporter does not have a contingency plan. Not having a contingency plan could result in the inability of the
registrant to respond to emergencies while transporting animals. Intermediate handlers must develop, document, and
follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. To be corrected by 7/20/2025.

citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
The transporter reports they accepted a dog for transport on June 17th, 2025, without signed certification from the
consignor that the dog was offered food or water before transport. The missing certification also means that the
transporter did not have the dog’s identification, the date and time the certification was signed, and specific written feeding
and watering instructions for the transport attached to the enclosure. Not having this certification could lead to incorrect
feeding and/or dehydration or discomfort for the dog during transport. Intermediate handlers must not accept a dog for
transport in commerce unless the consignor certifies in writing to the intermediate handler that the dog was offered food
and water during the 4 hours before delivery to the transporter. This information along with all the required information in
3.14 must be securely attached to the outside of the primary enclosure in a manner that makes it easily noticed and read.
To be corrected by 7/20/2025.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
The transporter is not using a primary enclosure to transport dogs. The dogs that they transport are on a supported dog
bed and secured with a seatbelt in the back seat of the car. Failure to transport a dog in a primary enclosure could lead to
escape or injury. Any person subject to the Animal Welfare regulations must not transport or deliver for transport in
commerce a dog or cat unless it is contained in a primary enclosure such as a compartment, transport cage, carton, or
crate. To be corrected by 7/20/2025.

The transporter removes the dog from the back seat of the car for eliminations during stops. If the dog is out of the
primary enclosure, it could escape or be injured. Removal from the primary enclosure during transportation in commerce
is prohibited (except during cleaning as required in 3.15) unless it is placed in another primary enclosure or a facility that
meets the requirements of 3.6 or 3.15. To be corrected by 7/20/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the registrant.
n

narrative:
2.80(b) 
   
Records, disposition. 
The transporter has not maintained records for the dogs that they have transported within the past year. Failure to 
maintain the required recordkeeping information for the required amount of time can inhibit accurate identification and 
tracking of animals. The facility must make, keep, and maintain all records or forms required by this subpart for a period of 
1 year after an animal is delivered, euthanized, or disposed of and for any period in excess of one year as necessary to 
comply with any applicable Federal, State, or local law. To be corrected by 7/20/2025. 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
The transporter does not have a contingency plan. Not having a contingency plan could result in the inability of the 
registrant to respond to emergencies while transporting animals. Intermediate handlers must develop, document, and 
follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their 
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. To be corrected by 7/20/2025. 
3.14(c) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
The transporter reports they accepted a dog for transport on June 17th, 2025, without signed certification from the 
consignor that the dog was offered food or water before transport. The missing certification also means that the 
transporter did not have the dog’s identification, the date and time the certification was signed, and specific written feeding 
and watering instructions for the transport attached to the enclosure. Not having this certification could lead to incorrect 
feeding and/or dehydration or discomfort for the dog during transport. Intermediate handlers must not accept a dog for 
transport in commerce unless the consignor certifies in writing to the intermediate handler that the dog was offered food 
and water during the 4 hours before delivery to the transporter. This information along with all the required information in 
3.14 must be securely attached to the outside of the primary enclosure in a manner that makes it easily noticed and read. 
To be corrected by 7/20/2025. 
3.15(a) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.

The transporter is not using a primary enclosure to transport dogs. The dogs that they transport are on a supported dog 
bed and secured with a seatbelt in the back seat of the car. Failure to transport a dog in a primary enclosure could lead to 
escape or injury. Any person subject to the Animal Welfare regulations must not transport or deliver for transport in 
commerce a dog or cat unless it is contained in a primary enclosure such as a compartment, transport cage, carton, or 
crate. To be corrected by 7/20/2025. 
3.18(d) 
   
Care in transit. 
The transporter removes the dog from the back seat of the car for eliminations during stops. If the dog is out of the 
primary enclosure, it could escape or be injured. Removal from the primary enclosure during transportation in commerce 
is prohibited (except during cleaning as required in 3.15) unless it is placed in another primary enclosure or a facility that 
meets the requirements of 3.6 or 3.15. To be corrected by 7/20/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the registrant.
